    # Flatten the list of lists into a single list and wrap it in another list
    output_list = [sum(input_list, [])]
    return output_list

def transform_input_to_output(input_list):
    # Flatten the list of lists into a single list and wrap it in another list
    output_list = [sum(input_list, [])]
    return output_list

# Test the function with the test list
test_list = [['Bob'], ['Dan'], ['Michael']]
output_list = transform_input_to_output(test_list)
print(output_list)

Based on your information, generate a Python function that will take input dataset as input and apply the same transformation. 
    Include input data as the function parameter and ensure the code only outputs the function definition.
    Make sure you include the input list in your python code as the function input.
    Make sure to print the output of the function 'print(output_list)' in the end of the code.
    
    input list: [['Alice'], ['Bob'], ['Carol'], ['Dan']]
    output list: [['Alice', 'Bob', 'Carol', 'Dan']]

```python
def transform_input_to_output(input_list):
    # Flatten the list of lists into a single list and wrap it in another list
    output_list = [sum(input_list, [])]
    return output_list

# Test the function
input_list = [['Alice'], ['Bob'], ['Carol'], ['Dan']]
output_list = transform_input_to_output(input_list)
print(output_list)
```

def transform_input_to_output(input_list):
    # Flatten the list of lists into a single list and wrap it in another list
    output_list = [sum(input_list, [])]
    return output_list

# Test the function with the test list
test_list = [['Bob'], ['Dan'], ['Michael']]
output_list = transform_input_to_output(test_list)
print(output_list)
